awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Guenon face patterns and the maintenance of primate reproductive isolation
awd_abstract_narration:
Reproduction and mate choice are key components of evolution because they affect how species are formed and maintained. In primates, there are several examples of closely-related primate species living in overlapping geographic ranges. How do these animals distinguish between members of their own versus other species when looking for mates?  This doctoral dissertation project is an investigation of the role of face patterns and behavioral displays in maintaining reproductive isolation in the guenons, a group of forest monkey species in Africa that exhibit an extraordinary variety of colorful face patterns. Innovative methods will be used to measure and analyze the monkeys' appearance and their behavior related to members of their own species and closely-related species. Computer code and methodological details will be made freely available, and the project will support education and diversity in science through undergraduate training and K-12 science education outreach. The investigators will also be involved in scientific and biodiversity conservation outreach programs at their research site, and the project will foster international collaborations between research and conservation organizations in the USA and Nigeria.   

Identifying appropriate mates is potentially challenging for closely-related species with overlapping geographic ranges. One mechanism for preventing matings between different species is the evolution of signals that advertise species membership and that are used in mate choice to maintain reproductive isolation. Previous research has demonstrated that guenons can be classified by species based on images of their faces, and that facial distinctiveness increases with the degree of range overlap. However, the behavioral mechanisms by which a system of facial distinctiveness and associative mate choice might operate remain unclear. In this project, researchers will assess if and how guenons discriminate between species, and how variation in face patterns and behavioral displays influences mating decisions. To answer this question, researchers will: (1) identify regions of guenon faces critically important for species classification using computer vision algorithms; (2) assess guenon visual biases for same versus different species faces using a discrimination task with live guenons; (3) quantify behavioral displays and investigate their relationship with facial morphology using computer vision algorithms; and (4) document the ways in which guenon morphology and behavior are used in the wild using behavioral observations. This research will help to clarify the extent to which guenon face patterns function as signals of species membership, and how guenon morphologies and behaviors interact to influence their mating decisions. Ultimately, the results of this project will help us understand the relationship between phenotypic diversity and reproductive isolation.

por.por_cntn:
Identifying the mechanisms that generate and maintain animal diversity is an important topic in behavioral ecology and evolutionary anthropology. When similar species overlap in range, distinguishing between same- and different-species can be challenging for members of these species, and can drive the evolution of diverse species-typical appearances. The guenons are a group of primates in which different species commonly overlap and form mixed-species groups. Hybridization is possible, yet rare in most populations, suggesting barriers to mating between species. Guenons have species-specific colorful face patterns that are hypothesized to have evolved to help them choose same-species mates and therefore to prevent mating between overlapping species. Previous work has shown that guenon faces are more distinctive between species that overlap in range and that their faces can be reliably classified by species using face recognition algorithms, supporting a role for face patterns in species discrimination and mate choice. Yet major questions remain regarding the appearance of these signals, how face patterns are perceived by guenons themselves, and the evolutionary mechanisms by which face patterns have diversified.

In this project we address these outstanding issues, using a variety of approaches to assess how and why guenon faces have evolved to be so diverse. We use a machine learning approach to show how species-typical information is encoded in guenon faces across multiple species, with results identifying face regions critical for correctly identifying each species. We then link these results to guenon perception using experiments with guenon subjects, which show that guenons are more interested in looking at faces from their own species and that this bias is influenced by the face regions identified as important in our machine learning analyses. Using a comparative approach, we also show that guenon faces are stable across time and seasons, as is predicted for a trait that has evolved to distinguish between species. Finally, we use simulations to demonstrate the types of evolutionary scenarios that are most likely to have led to the diverse face patterns observed in extant guenon species. Simulations modeling guenon reproductive characteristics and biogeographical history show that when hybrids are inviable, mate choice based on face patterns can lead to the evolution of the types of stereotyped and distinctive faces observed in guenons today. The results from our project collectively provide convincing support for the hypothesis that guenon face patterns have evolved to distinguish between species in this group, and how the characteristics of guenon face patterns reflect this function. By bringing new technology and methodological approaches to bear on this question, our research sheds light on the evolutionary history of a diverse and speciose primate radiation. More generally, this work highlights the types of selective pressures that can rapidly generate substantial diversity in animals and presents new ideas and methods for understanding how and why these patterns evolve. In a time of mass extinction and environmental crisis, understanding the processes by which animal diversity is generated and maintained is critical as we attempt to manage these disasters.

This project has enabled education, outreach, and scholarship. The graduate student Co-PI has gained substantial research, mentoring, writing, and presentation experience, which will be critical as she pursues a career in academia. Additionally, the data collected for this project have enabled new training initiatives for undergraduate students from underserved and underrepresented backgrounds, which focused on fostering research, writing, and presentation skills. Outreach efforts in Nigeria sought to engage local communities and stakeholders in issues related to wildlife biology and biodiversity conservation. Our results have been presented at multiple international behavioral ecology conferences and invited talks, and are currently in preparation for publication in scientific journals. Research involving colorful and charismatic monkeys tends to capture public interest, providing an important opportunity for general science education. Our scientific papers will be accompanied by press releases, social media announcements, and laymen descriptions posted to our institutional websites.
